Dear Ms. Pettway:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
04/20/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Linda Tansil at 248-860-0787.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
(3) The training specified in subrule (2)(a) and (b) of this
rule shall address all of the following areas:
(h) Emergency procedures, first aid, and fire safety.
Three of eight foster home files reviewed did not provide updated CPR/first aid
training for the foster parents.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Seven of eight foster care files (fourteen of the twenty – seven service plans) were
not submitted timely within the 90 days prior to the service plan due date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
INTERIM 11/19/2021, CAP APPROVED 12/1/2021

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
Renewal Inspections completed on 11/19/2021 and CAP submitted on 12/1/2021.
There were three repeat violations during this interim review. The agency
implemented the CAP effectively with the exception of four repeat violations. The
repeat violations were with Rule 400.12418 Development of Service Plans, FOM
722-06B Family Team Meeting, and FOM 801-03 Medical Passport.
There were three Special investigations:
Special investigation #2022C0106006 was generated on 3/3/2022. Agency was in
violation with Rules 418 (1), Fom 801-3 and MCL 712A. CAP was appproved on
7/5/2022. The agency is following their CAP. This was vertified during the CAP
folow-up that occurred on site. Agency program manager and supervisor are
providing training to staff on a quarterly basis. The agency has created a tracking
system for monitoring the violations for this investigation and the supervisor is
monitoring it closely.
Special Investigation #2022C0201020 was generated on 3/3/2022. Agency was
in violations with Rule 400.12713 Adoption placement record. The CAP was
approved on 8/16/22. The agency created a form that is attached to the closed
adoption file with dates of closure and where to send the case within the time
frame of the case being close. This is being monitored and reviewed by the
supervisors. It was vertified during the CAP follow-up on site.
4

Special investigation #2022C0420015, generated on 3/21/2022, violation with
Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation. The CAP ws approved on 6/14/2022. CAP
compliance was vertified at the agency during CAP follow-up. The agency is
adhering to their CAP and held training with staff on 7/7/22 and 8/7/22 with all
staff.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The CAA was discussed in detail during the exit conference. The agency
struggled this reporting period was with the move from their prior location to the
new location and losing key staff and having to hire qualified staff to replace the
employees that was terminated or resigned. This placed the agency at a loss with
getting paperwork completed timely. Employees also had to be trained and this
was a large barrier for the agency.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted their annual report, and the nonprofit tax return.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were positive. One staff had worked in the agency as an intern,
so this was a good fit for the agency because she was aware of the paperwork
that came along with the job. Staff praised their administration and coworkers.
They love working as a team and the amount of respect they receive from doing
their job from the administrative staff. The staff interviewed stated they enjoy
helping families and being out in the community.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no safety concerns noted.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts. They were completed and resolved.
Alert # 1
Concern:
The home does not have a smoke and carbon monoxide detector properly installed.
There is no smoke detector located upstairs and in the basement.
Resolution:
The safety alert was completed on 1/4/2023. Pictures were uploaded to ensure the
alert was completed.
Alert #2
Concern:
The home has a bed in the basement, and it’s used by her 19-year-old son. The
basement does not have a proper means of egress. According to the foster Parent
5

she is pursuing licensure.
Resolution:
On 12/9/, the worker went to the home and observed that the move occurred as
discussed and her son is no longer residing in the basement and is now on the main
floor of the home. Pictures were uploaded to show the home is in compliance.
Alert #3
Concern:
The unlicensed relative provider refused to comply with a home visit, therefore safety of
the home and children could not be verified. A safety alert is being submitted with a
request for the agency to verify the safety of the home and children.
Resolution:
The agency responded to the safety alert by doing a safety check of the home on
11/22/22. The agency did not discover safety issues.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Bethany Christian Services INC. – Madison Heights continue
on their regular license.
